postsData.content:
𝟱 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝘆𝘁𝗵𝘀 (𝗕𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗱)

Many people think productivity is about doing more—but the truth? It’s about doing the right things.

Let’s break some myths:
 Myth #1: "Work-Life Balance is the Key to Success"
 Reality: Prioritization changes everything. Trying to “balance” everything leads to burnout. The real game-changer? Knowing what actually moves the needle.

 Myth #2: "You Just Need More Motivation"
 Reality: You can’t fix what you don’t diagnose. If you’re feeling stuck, the problem isn’t motivation—it’s clarity. Fix the strategy, and momentum follows.

 Myth #3: "Hard Work Guarantees Results"
 Reality: Ownership & accountability drive success. Effort without direction is wasted energy. The most successful people don’t just work hard—they work smart and take responsibility.

 Myth #4: "More Meetings = More Progress"
 Reality: Meetings without clear purpose kill productivity. If you’re constantly in meetings, ask yourself—are you actually getting things done or just talking about them?

 Myth #5: "Delegation Solves Everything"
 Reality: Delegation without clarity leads to even worse inefficiency. Before you delegate, make sure you understand what’s actually important. Ownership matters.

 𝗕𝗼𝘁𝘁𝗼𝗺 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲:
 Clarity on priorities changes everything.
 You can’t fix what you don’t diagnose.
 Ownership & accountability drive success.

 Want to go deeper on this? DM me—I may have a solution for you.

comments.commentText: This is an excellent,substantive, and actionable post. Thank you!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! 🏆 Prioritization and clarity truly transform productivity. Let’s focus on working smart, not just hard! 💡

Marianna Outsia
Marianna Outsia
postsData.content:
I spent too much time forcing myself to 
stay in places where I clearly didn’t belong.
At first, I thought I could adjust. I convinced myself I just 

needed to try harder, be more patient,

or lower my expectations.

But no matter how much effort I put in,

the discomfort never went away.


One day, I realized the truth:

It wasn’t about me trying to fit in…

it was about recognizing that some places

will never feel right, no matter what you do.


So, I made the choice to leave.

To stop shrinking myself to fit

into spaces that weren’t made for me

and start creating

something that truly felt like home.


LinkedIn gives me the freedom to explore,

to share my voice,

and to connect with people

who align with my vision.

It isn’t just a platform…

it’s a breath of fresh air

that allows me to build the career and life I truly want.


If you’re stuck somewhere

that doesn’t feel right,

maybe it’s time to ask yourself:

What would happen if I just walked away?


You deserve to be

in a space where you can grow…

not just survive.
postsData.commentAdded: Powerful reflection! 🌟 Recognizing when to leave is key to growth. Heres to creating spaces where we thrive! #Authenticity #CareerGrowth

postsData.content:
What Makes a Great Leader? 

I Asked 25 CEOs—Here’s What They Said."
When I was prepping for my latest op-ed in [Insert Magazine Name], I could’ve just googled “leadership tips” and called it a day. But where’s the fun in that?
So, I reached out to 25 CEOs—real people leading real companies through real challenges—and asked them one simple question:

“What does leadership mean to you?

The answers? 
Some were profound. Some were unexpected. Some made me pause, sip my coffee, and think, “Damn, that’s good.”

A few favorites:
1️⃣ “Leadership isn’t about being the smartest person in the room—it’s about creating a room where everyone feels smart.”
2️⃣ “Great leaders don’t have all the answers. They just ask better questions.”
3️⃣ “It’s not about having power; it’s about how you use it when no one’s watching.”

I've uploaded the first of five I will share this is from Nick Egan, PhD.

Writing this article wasn’t just another assignment—it was a masterclass. A reminder that leadership isn’t about titles, corner offices, or LinkedIn buzzwords. It’s about impact, integrity, and influence.

 What’s the best leadership advice you’ve ever received? Drop it in the comments—I’d love to hear your take.
postsData.commentAdded: Love this perspective! Leadership truly shines when we empower others. Excited to see more insights from your interviews! 🌟

postsData.content:
These days, young people are told to title-hop FAST.

Manager one year. 
Director the next.
VP before you hit 30.

It sounds ambitious, but here’s the problem:

Speed kills depth.
Depth builds mastery.
Mastery makes great leaders.

When you skip steps, you miss the lessons:

Managing people, not just tasks.
Recovering from failure.
Seeing the bigger picture.

Your career isn’t a sprint.

It’s a marathon.

If you spend:

Your 20s experimenting…
Your 30s mastering…
Your 40s leading…

You’ll lead with clarity, not insecurity.

So stop chasing titles.

Start chasing growth.

The best leaders aren’t the ones who climb the fastest. They’re the ones who learned the most along the way.

Your career spans 50+ years.

Why rush?

️ Repost to help your network.

postsData.name:
Isabel Sterne 🟡
Isabel Sterne 🟡
postsData.content:
"You seem a lot happier now," my dad told me on the phone yesterday.

For most of my career that wasn't the case.

Throughout my 15+ years in marketing, I often felt stuck, depressed, and completely disengaged.

It wasn't really an issue with the companies or leadership (though there were moments :) but more an issue with the lack of autonomy, creative freedom, and constant holding patterns of waiting for approvals.

At first, I thought that it might have to do with the type of organization I was working at, so I jumped around a bunch—tried nonprofits, for-profits, associations, you name it.

No matter what I did, nothing felt right.

But I pushed through anyway because, "That's why they call it 'work'," plus, you know, all those other practical reasons like I needed money to pay for housing and food.

It was all going until a couple of years ago when I got laid off (for the third time) and decided I couldn't keep doing this.

It felt like I was running into a wall over and over again and expecting different results.

I wasn't getting any happier or any more secure.

I realized, as Jim Carrey so eloquently put it, "You can fail at what you don't want, so you might as well take a chance on doing what you love."

When I reflected on what had really given me energy during the high points of my career, I realized that one of my favorite jobs was working with a solopreneur/founder based in California who supported communities after traumatic events (e.g. natural disasters, violence, etc.)

I liked it because:

- I loved the founder
- I felt we were doing impactful work
- She trusted me to do my job
- Gave me autonomy and creative license to try new things
- The flexibility to work how and when I wanted

It was like being an entrepreneur with training wheels.

Having watched her create such an impactful organization on her own + watching my parents build their own business made me feel like I could do it too, so I did :)

I still have a lot to figure out and won't pretend that I've "made it," but I do feel way happier in my day-to-day.

I can finally create stuff on my terms, meet interesting people from around the world, and help other entrepreneurs build their dreams.

Turns out my favorite job ended up being the one I created for myself.

If you're feeling stuck in your work situation, take a moment to think about the aspects of your career that energized you.

It might not be related to the industry, salary, or job title. It could be the way you worked, the people you interacted with, or the schedule it afforded you.

Find what lights you up and keep going in that direction. If you're like me, it might mean going down a new path you create for yourself.

Happy Friday 

-

Image: [Isabel happily drinking a watermelon drink]

comments.commentText:
No words, except one… inspirational

And one more… wise

OK, a third… awesome!

postsData.commentAdded: What an inspiring journey, Isabel! Your story is a powerful reminder that sometimes we need to create our own paths to find true fulfillment. 🌟

Stav Vaisman
postsData.content:
Most of us are asking the wrong question about innovation.

We focus on "How do we generate more ideas?"

But we should be asking: Have I created a place where the ideas we already have can actually thrive?

Not just where they can be presented.

Not where they can be pitched.

But where they can truly develop.

- Do people share rough drafts or only polished thoughts?
- Are questions welcomed or seen as disruptions?
- Do half-formed ideas get space to develop?
- Can anyone's concept reach decision-makers?

I've learned that innovation thrives in environments of psychological safety, not perfect conditions.

I'd rather have a team that feels safe sharing bad ideas than one that only shares safe ones.

Because here's what I've learned about great ideas:

They don't start great.

They start fragile.

Uncertain.

Incomplete.

They need space to stumble.

To evolve.

To transform.

That's the real work of leadership - not building idea spaces, but building trust spaces.

comments.commentText: This perspective on innovation really emphasizes the importance of nurturing our thought processes together.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Creating a culture of psychological safety is vital for nurturing innovation. Trust is the foundation for great ideas to flourish!

postsData.content:
People don’t remember facts. They remember stories.

You’ve probably forgotten most of the stats you read last week.
But that one powerful story? The one that hit you emotionally? Still stuck in your head.

That’s the power of storytelling.

And no, it’s not just for books.

Storytelling is what makes people pay attention, on LinkedIn, in your branding, in your business, everywhere.

Because let’s be real, no one wants to read:

 “We are a leading company in XYZ industry.”
 “I am a highly experienced professional with 10+ years of expertise.”
 “Our product has amazing features like A, B, and C.”

Yawn.

People don’t connect with fancy words and robotic statements. They connect with real, human stories.

 A struggle you faced and how you overcame it
 A mistake that taught you a big lesson
 A weird, unexpected moment that changed your thinking
 A client success story that actually feels real

That’s what makes people stop scrolling. That’s what builds a brand people trust.

So, how do you develop this skill? Start practicing storytelling EVERYWHERE.

Your LinkedIn posts? Tell a story.
Your sales pitch? Tell a story.
Your personal brand? Root it in your story.

Because the brands that win? They don’t just sell. They tell stories that make people feel something.


 P.S. If you want to use storytelling to make your brand unforgettable, DM me. Let’s make your words matter.

comments.commentText: Crafting messages around true experiences seems like a great way to build trust and connection.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Storytelling is the heartbeat of connection. It’s what resonates and leaves a lasting impact. Let’s start sharing those stories! 🚀 #Storytelling

postsData.content:
Time doesn’t stop for anyone.

We can’t pause or rewind it.

Work can be fulfilling, but it can also be all-consuming. When we let it take over, we risk missing the moments that truly matter.

Many ambitions promise happiness:
- A high salary.
- Luxury holidays.
- Career success.
- A bigger house.

However, these often mask deeper struggles:
- Burnout.
- Missed family moments.
- Unhealthy habits.
- No time for yourself.

None of these trade-offs are worth it.

No amount of money can buy back lost time.

You can't give your life more time, so give the time you have left more life.
The best investment you can make is in the moments that bring you real joy.

(Thanks to TheOpenInvite for the excellent visual).

P.S. - What’s your time worth?

️ Repost to help a friend prioritise what matters.

postsData.content:
️ Accelerate AI: 60 Seconds of Brilliance | High-Dimensional Intelligence

AI isn’t magic—it’s just optimization in high-dimensional function spaces. But most researchers treat it like trial-and-error.

Every new model is just another point in a vast landscape, yet few understand the terrain. They scale, tweak, and hope—wasting compute.

What if you could predict emergent intelligence before training?

Physics already maps the space: intelligence emerges at criticality, where constraints shape stable attractors. The best models don’t just train; they converge to fundamental structures.

Stop guessing. Start designing intelligence with physics.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating perspective! Harnessing physics to navigate the AI landscape could revolutionize model design and efficiency. Excited for what’s ahead!

Patrick Spielmann
Patrick Spielmann
postsData.content:
Here's how I know at least Google (probably MS) are using ML/AI to process emails...

A customer setup 200 email accounts in Uptics and started warming them.

The problem is the warmup score would not get above 70-80% on 20 of them.

I couldn't figure it out.

They were brand new domains.

Then I asked the customer...

"Have you used these usernames for email inboxes before?"

And low and behold the 20 having issues were recycled names.

They had used them in previous campaigns (that probably got flagged).

But on different domains.

After digging in further, the domain name also had a company key term in it.

This cemented for me that the email gods are doing a lot to filter emails.

Knowing that, every precaution should be taken for your cold emails.

Even if you think "There's no way they are doing that".

They are.

Plan on it.

Bet on it.

That's why things like...

Decentralization & AI Spintax shouldn't be slept on.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! It’s clear that email filters are becoming more sophisticated. Adapting our strategies is essential for successful outreach! 📧🌐

My first coaching sessions as a novice coach immediately brought a humbling realisation:
𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗅

 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗅

postsData.content:
Why are companies prioritizing Agentic RAG over traditional retrieval methods to build more autonomous and intelligent applications?

Well, traditional RAG systems are constrained by static workflows and lack the adaptability required for multi-step reasoning and complex task management.

Agentic RAG represents an advanced approach that enhances traditional RAG systems by integrating intelligent agents capable of autonomous decision-making and multi-step reasoning.

Unlike conventional RAG models that primarily utilize LLMs for straightforward question answering, Agentic RAG employs specialized agents to navigate complex queries requiring detailed analysis and planning.

These agents function similarly to expert researchers, adeptly retrieving relevant information from multiple sources, comparing data, and synthesizing comprehensive responses.

This dynamic approach allows for improved contextual understanding and adaptability, enabling the system to respond more effectively to diverse user needs.

The architecture of Agentic RAG includes components such as an input layer for user queries, retrieval mechanisms that leverage various tools (like web searches and APIs), and a generation phase where coherent responses are crafted based on the retrieved information.

By allowing agents to evaluate which tools to use and when to re-retrieve data, Agentic RAG significantly enhances the flexibility and efficiency of information retrieval processes.

Moreover, it supports real-time adjustments based on user intent, making it particularly valuable in environments where understanding nuanced queries is essential.

Applications of Agentic RAG span various fields, including research assistance, customer support, and knowledge management, where its ability to deliver precise and contextually relevant answers can greatly enhance productivity and decision-making.

Overall, Agentic RAG marks a substantial evolution in AI technologies, transforming passive information retrieval into an active investigative process that leverages external knowledge for superior outcomes.

postsData.content:
AI in healthcare is only as strong as the data it’s built on. Here’s why quality data is crucial for maximizing AI’s impact in patient care:

1️⃣ Accuracy and Reliability
→ Reliable data ensures AI models make accurate decisions. In healthcare, precision is everything—faulty data can lead to misdiagnoses and unsafe treatment plans, putting patient safety at risk.

2️⃣ Bias Mitigation
→ High-quality, diverse datasets reduce bias, ensuring AI algorithms treat all demographics fairly. This helps address health disparities and promotes equitable care.

3️⃣ Improved Patient Outcomes
→ Quality data enables tailored treatments, enhancing clinical decision support and driving better patient outcomes through personalized care.

4️⃣ Operational Efficiency
→ Clean, organized data streamlines processes like patient enrollment and reduces administrative tasks, allowing healthcare teams to focus on patient care instead of data management.

The takeaway? In healthcare, data quality is not a “nice-to-have”—it’s essential for safe, effective AI applications.

Ready to unlock AI’s full potential with high-quality data? Let’s talk.

Scientists fed rabbits a diet extremely high in cholesterol, expecting their health to decline.

And it did—for most of them.

But one group of rabbits remained perfectly healthy. No high cholesterol. No negative effects.

The difference? 𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘸𝘦𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘥 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘭𝘰𝘷𝘦.

Unlike the others, these rabbits were fed by a researcher who stroked them gently, spoke to them kindly, and handled them with care.

And that simple act of affection changed their entire metabolic response.

Their bodies processed the same toxic food differently, preventing the usual damage.

This study proved something profound: 𝘠𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘦𝘮𝘰𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘪𝘯𝘧𝘭𝘶𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘣𝘰𝘥𝘺 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘦.

Stress, fear, and negativity can turn even the best circumstances toxic.
Compassion, love, and mindfulness can neutralise even the worst situations.

So, ask yourself—how do you see the challenges in your life?

Are they obstacles breaking you down?
Or stepping stones helping you grow?

99% of the harm happens in your mind—only 1% comes from reality.

It’s all about perspective.

postsData.content:
Building in public takes courage. Admitting failure takes more.

After 3.5 years, I’ve made the decision to dissolve.

It’s bittersweet, but more than anything, I’m proud of what we built and grateful for everyone who supported us along the way.

BuzzU started with a simple yet ambitious goal: turn data into dollars for the 99% of college athletes who weren’t landing million-dollar NIL deals.

Along the way we built a proprietary algorithm, 50,000 athlete database, AI-ChatBot solution and many partnerships.

We pivoted, adapted, and pushed forward in an ever-changing NIL landscape—one that remains filled with uncertainty today.

While this chapter is closing, I walk away with zero regrets and endless gratitude—for the investors, advisors, and teammates who believed in this vision from day one.

From the start, my goal was to build something bigger than myself and be transparent throughout the process.

“I would rather be a failed entrepreneur than someone who never tried. Because even a failed entrepreneur has the skill set to make it on their own.” - Naval Ravikant

More to come.

postsData.content:
How Swiggy has pushed us all to use the "Eco saver" delivery option. 

You see two options on Swiggy whenever you order:
Standard order (20-30 mins delivery)
and Eco saver (30-40 mins delivery)

I was recently wondering how Swiggy actually reduces carbon footprints by just delaying the delivery by 10 mins.

Here's what I found:
Swiggy says that their riders travel millions of Kms per day and a small step can amount to a significant dent on their part.

Grouping orders
Swiggy groups orders in and around your delivery location and delivers all the orders together, saving extra travel.

states:
" So far, we have been able to cut CO2 emissions by more than 300 tonnes, that’s the equivalent of planting 10k+ trees! "

But it wasn't that simple,
When Swiggy introduced this, people were reluctant to opt for a late delivery.

What if the food becomes stale ?
What if it's not hot ?
How will Swiggy actually save carbon footprints?

This "anxiety" factor refrained people from using this option.

Swiggy quickly realised this and attacked the pain point of the users.

Monetary benifit:
They introduced a nominal discount.

 Gratification of doing something good:
They made their customers feel good about contributing to the environment by introducing keywords in the Eco saver badge such as " Less fuel pollution"

 It removed the element of surprise:
Earlier they themselves grouped orders without the customers approval. Now the provide us with two badges.


And today, when I used this Eco saver badge for delivery, I was amazed to see the order getting delivered under 30 mins. That's how much they have optimised the grouping!


----
If you are still reading, I assume you found the article an interesting read, let me know your favorite part of it in the comments.

Image source:blogs

comments.commentText: It took them 9 months and 30+ variants to finally achieve a stable delivery option.

Swiggy’s sustainable marketing move isn’t just smart—it’s the future of brand loyalty! ️ By embracing eco-friendly packaging and green deliveries, they’re serving up impact alongside convenience. Consumers love brands that care, and this strategy will drive deeper engagement and trust. Expect stronger customer retention, industry leadership, and a ripple effect on sustainable business models. Swiggy isn’t just delivering food—it’s delivering change!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! It’s impressive how small changes, like opting for the Eco saver, can lead to big environmental impacts. Kudos to Swiggy for innovation! 🌍✨

postsData.name:
Anamika Nayak
Anamika Nayak
postsData.content:
This morning, I opened my LinkedIn and work email to 87 pitches-all claiming to “10x my revenue” with SEO, “guaranteed leads” via digital marketing, or “transform my business” overnight.

The irony?

I don’t even have a traditional business. I’ve been freelancing and running micro-projects for years. Yet, my inbox looks like I’m CEO of a Fortune 500 company.

If I’m drowning in this noise as a solopreneur, I can’t imagine what actual business owners face daily. The sheer volume of unsolicited “solutions” is overwhelming and I’ve learned to sniff out the empty promises. Most of these messages are copy-pasted, irrelevant, or worse… scams dressed as “partnerships.”

But instead of deleting them all, I did something radical: I replied.

I asked: “Why me?”

The answers were telling:
60% ghosted.
30% sent templated excuses.
10% actually paused… and apologized.

This isn’t just about spam-it’s about how we define “expertise” today. When everyone claims to be a guru, no one is. The noise isn’t just annoying-it erodes trust for the legit professionals doing the work.

The New Lens-- ️‍️

To the salespeople in my DMs: I get it. Algorithms reward activity, not authenticity. Quotas are ruthless. But here’s the truth:

Freelancers like me don’t need “10x growth.” We need partners who ask, “What’s your actual goal?”

Business owners don’t want another vendor. They want collaborators who listen first.

comments.commentText:
Let’s talk math, not magic.

Talk money-making maps and revenue iteration because this kind of outreach doesn’t just waste time, it ruins reputations.

When pitches focus on fluff instead of math, everyone loses. What if every cold message came with a clear win-win equation? “Here’s how we’ll move from
X to Y and why it works for both of us.”

No hype. No empty promises. Just real numbers, real results.
my business is so small I'm pretty sure these salespeople are pitching me on becoming their intern it's funny but it's also frustrating

postsData.commentAdded: Well said! Its crucial for salespeople to focus on genuine partnerships rather than just hitting quotas. Authenticity fosters real connections.

postsData.content:
Disturbance in the force.

-I'm seeing lots of paid-per-job offers, where the job is large in time but considered small in cost.

-Very short term contract, (less than 3 months) offered to solve a critical company issues without long term gain to the solver.

-Hourly pay rate is lower than previous years.

-Salary expectations for top roles are much lower than previous years & posted as such.

-Remote roles are rarer by the day.

-Company sending test to applicants, just to fix an internal business issue for free.

-Job posting remaining open/active for over 6 months for regular roles .

-Companies doing layoff's just to keep similar active roles open and advertised.

-Drop down list application where the applicant actual sex and age are asked.

-Ghosting is now a common practice.

-Writing cover letter doesn't have the weight it used to, if any.

-Overqualified applicant are now omitting on purpose any higher learning education or past job experience just to appear less qualified on paper if applying to a lower skilled job.

-Overqualified professional cannot find basic jobs to pay the bills.

-Agism is real and job scams are everywhere.

-Looking for jobs is a lonely experience & a soul crushing one for that matter, but where true honesty shared is a dangerous slope.

The positive.
-Companies are whiling to move you across the globe for a job.

-Time zones are melting for remote roles, if you can shift it locally to match theirs.

-Language barriers is uncommon now.

-Large multi-studios spread thin companies are settling into just a few key location(s).

-Software and toolset for the job are now free or cheap to obtain.

-Recruitment appears to be getting hired more these days vs 6 months ago.

-LinkedIn is filled with great artists visually showcasing their art daily, the community is vibrant.

BTW, I may just be full of it, but that's simply my perception, open for thoughts.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 5 – CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today’s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights on redefining intelligence! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is crucial for true innovation in AI. Looking forward to seeing this evolve!

Startup Pedia
Startup Pedia
postsData.content:
A Bengaluru-based IIT Kharagpur graduate has developed an Artificial Intelligence tool that measures how round a roti (chapati) is and then gives it a score out of 100.

According to Moneycontrol, it all started when a social media user posted a picture of a round chapati and added a caption that read, “Gol roti banana bhi ek art hai.”

Responding to it, Animesh Chouhan introduced his AI tool calledand gave the user’s chapati a score of 91 out of 100.

The post quickly went viral on the Internet and the IIT Kharagpur graduate stated that he would release the AI tool for public use if his post achieved 420 likes. Animesh wrote, “420 likes andgoes public! ”

: BUILT AS A JOKE

Animesh Chouhan said that he developedas a joke during his free time. But after it received a lot of traction on social media, he is now thinking of taking the project ahead and even seeking investment.

Joking about offering 10% equity in return, Chouhan said he would seek investment in order to get the domain name.

Currently, the website shows the following text:

“
Dough or Die: The Great Gol Roti Challenge

Coming soon…”

NETIZENS REACT

Animesh Chouhan’s invention received a lot of responses from social media users. While some suggested the need for more tools like, others gave feedback on the tool itself.

One user wrote, “So Indian developers are busy in making such craps, i see.” Animesh responded by saying that the tool only took him 5 minutes to make.

A second user wrote, “The US has ChatGPT, China has DeepSeek, and we have.”

In a sarcastic comment directed to OpenAI’s Sam Altman, another user wrote, “sit down sama, India has arrived.”

One individual also pointed out that the tool measures only a roti’s shape, not its thickness. According to them, the thickness of a roti is also a key factor in determining the taste and texture.

The tool also received some backlash for being misogynist. One user wrote, “how about programming something that’s not misogynistic or based on a particular gender next time.”

Animesh countered by writing, “Who said this platform is only for women? If you assumed that, then that's your own misogyny showing, not mine. We have men posting here too. Cheers!”

postsData.content:
WHO WEARS YOUR COAT?

A dog and a cat—different in so many ways, yet similar in coat.

They walk through the halls side by side.
They rest in the same spot, never far from one another.
They move through life as if they’ve never known a world without each other.

Because they haven’t.
From the beginning, they’ve had each other’s backs.
Through every moment, they stayed.

And maybe that’s a reminder for all of us.

Do you have someone in your life who wears the same color coat?

Not the coat of fur, but the coat of friendship.

The ones who believed in you before anyone else did.
The ones who supported you without expecting anything in return.
The ones who walked beside you when the road was uncertain.

Life gets busy. Success changes things. New opportunities, new circles, new surroundings.

But some people? They’ve never taken their coat off for you.

Not everyone will stay on the journey.

But the ones who do—the ones who stay through the struggles, the doubts, and the failures—don’t forget about them.

Stay humble.
Stay grateful.
Stay connected to the ones who’ve always stood by your side.

Because in the end, titles fade, money comes and goes, and achievements are replaced.

But the ones who’ve been there for you from the beginning? They are priceless.

If you enjoy my posts please follow me:

Kathryn V.


and our team at Life Lessons Series,- Founder

postsData.content:
An objection can feel like a slap in the face (if you don't know how to handle it)

How I handle top 10 sales objections:

Every objection is an opportunity for discovery - peel the onion.

1 “Email me in 3 months"
- What will happen in 3 months?

2 “I’m not interested"
- Before I leave - Is <challenge> a priority right now? if not, what is?

3 “Too expensive”
- It sounds like you're comparing this to what you already have or just the value isn't there for you. Which one is it?

4 “We don’t have the budget”
- Budget aside, is this even close to a priority for 2025?

5 “I’m locked into a contract with a competitor”
- Anything you’d want to improve with your current solution?

6 “tried it & it didn’t work for us”
- Could you tell me more about what didn’t work?

7 “We just signed a contract with a provider”
- Would you want to explore other options before renewal, just to compare?

8 “We already use a competitor”
- Would you be open to hearing 3 ways we differ?

9 “All set for now”
- Just so I’m clear, what’s working well that you feel all set on?

10 I’m too busy right now

Don't fight the objection, get to the real why.

That's the art of verbal judo.

How do you handle objections?

BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 6 – The RKE Paradigm
The RYLTI Knowledge Engineering (RKE} Paradigm is a revolutionary approach to analytics and discovery based on a combination of the latest science, innovative methodology and a patent-pending biomimetic technology.

Unlike the 70-year-old Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) paradigm which has succeeded only in scaling expenditures and hype while achieving sparse utility, RKE continues to deliver high value insights and outcomes. The primary enablers of RKE success are:
·        Biomimicry – imitating what works all around us, all the time, rather than investing in large scale random experimentation.
·        Real-world Development Lab – the innovative methods have been designed and tested as components of successful enterprise solutions.
·        Realistic Target – rather than trying to match and exceed human intelligence, of which we have limited knowledge and conflicting theories, RKE enables analytics tools that leverage human expertise together with what we do know about intelligence.

High Value Use Case Examples
a.     Complex Decision Processes
-F50 bank needed to select new technology and vendor for global implementation. The decision process required 50+ SVP & VP participants, with an estimated duration of 18 months.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software was used by the project manager to model all the RFP requirements to the responders’ documents, leading to a nearly unanimous decision in 12 weeks.
b.     Transforming Data into New Knowledge
-Leading research university and hospital looking to find genetic variants of unknown significance that could be linked to endometriosis and potentially reclassified, but there were only 18 patient samples available.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software were used to build a digital twin ecosystem of the problem enabled discovery of previously unseen multidimensional and multiscale relationships. The results were published in the Journal of Molecular Diagnostics.
c.     Modeling Organizations as Complex, Dynamic Systems
-F50 Pharma was accountable for seven distinct domains of regulations and standards, and seven operational groups monitored changes in requirements and internal compliance.
-RKE Paradigm methodology and software were used to model the people, processes, technology, and information required as a dynamic ecosystem of organizational competency units, enabling a 70% resource reduction. The executive sponsor won the company’s highest innovation award.

There is a significant gap between the RKE Paradigm and traditional architectures. The diagram in the image describes how the architectures can collaborate.

postsData.content:
Provisoning For Telcos/Carriers Is About understanding the process well

- Order Processing Automation
- Service Provisioning
- Integration Capabilities
- Real-time Tracking
- Customizable Workflows

1. Accurate Order Capture:

Comprehensive Customer Data: Capture all necessary customer details (contact information, service address, desired services, etc.) accurately and completely. This minimizes errors and delays later in the process.
Clear Service Catalog: Provide a user-friendly catalog with detailed descriptions of available services, pricing, and terms. This ensures customers understand what they're ordering and sets clear expectations.
Order Validation: Implement checks to ensure order accuracy and completeness before proceeding. This can include automated checks for address validity, service compatibility, and credit checks.

2. Efficient Order Processing:

Automated Workflows: Streamline order processing with automated workflows that route orders to the appropriate departments and trigger necessary tasks. This reduces manual intervention and speeds up the process.
Integration with Inventory Systems: Ensure real-time visibility into available resources (equipment, network capacity, etc.) to prevent over-provisioning and delays.
Service Activation: Automate the technical steps required to activate services, such as configuring network elements, assigning phone numbers, and provisioning devices.
3. Robust Order Tracking and Management:

Real-time Order Status Updates: Provide customers with visibility into their order status throughout the process, from order placement to service activation.
Proactive Communication: Keep customers informed about potential delays or issues and provide timely updates.
Order Modification and Cancellation: Allow customers to easily modify or cancel their orders, with clear processes for handling changes and refunds.
4. Seamless Integration with Other Systems:

CRM Integration: Integrate order management with CRM systems to provide a unified view of customer interactions and service history.
Billing System Integration: Ensure accurate and timely billing by integrating order management with billing systems.
Network Management Systems: Integrate with network management systems to monitor service performance and proactively address potential issues.
5. Continuous Improvement and Optimization:

Performance Monitoring: Track key metrics like order fulfillment time, error rates, and customer satisfaction to identify areas for improvement.
Process Optimization: Regularly review and optimize processes to eliminate bottlenecks and improve efficiency.
Feedback Mechanisms: Collect customer feedback and use it to improve the overall order management experience.

By focusing on these elements and implementing them in a logical and integrated manner, telecom companies can achieve efficient provisioning, improve customer satisfaction, and reduce operational costs.

Insightful

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on optimizing order processing for telcos! Emphasizing automation and customer communication is key to enhancing satisfaction.

postsData.content:
Yesterday, I had an insightful chat with a CEO of a high-growth B2B demand generation agency. We debated B2B buying in the age of AI... 

We discussed how buying journeys are evolving in the new world of AI.

Watching the latest insights from OpenAI how Sales agents take over all the mundane tasks SDRs and AEs are executing on a daily basis now.

One thing becomes clear: Your buyers are done waiting for live sales calls.

They want answers—on their time.

B2B buying has changed. Yet, most revenue teams still rely on the same outdated playbook:

• Cold outbound. Generic decks. Endless follow-ups.
• Forcing meetings when buyers would rather self-educate.
• Ignoring the fact that buyers only spend 5 percent of their journey engaging with vendors.

Your champion? They’re drowning in internal discussions.
Your decision-makers? They weren’t even in the room.

The old way of selling is breaking. The best teams today are closing deals asynchronously.

𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗕𝘂𝘆𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗔𝘃𝗼𝗶𝗱 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗿𝘀
They don’t dislike you. They just prefer to engage on their own time.

• They check LinkedIn on their commute.
• They research at night after their kids are in bed.
• They debate your proposal in Slack—not on your follow-up call.

If your entire sales process depends on live meetings, you’re already losing.

Instead, the best revenue teams sell between meetings.

𝟱 𝗔𝘀𝘆𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗼𝘂𝘀 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗧𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗠𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗔𝗱𝗼𝗽𝘁

1) Ditch Cold Emails—Engage on LinkedIn Instead
• Most sales emails are ignored. LinkedIn DMs get 3-5x more replies.
• Connect with buyers before they are in-market.
• Comment on their posts 3x per week so you’re visible before outreach even starts.

2) Use Video to Reinforce Key Takeaway
• Buyers forget 80% of what was said in your meeting.
• A 2-minute video recap keeps your value fresh.

3) Pre-Demo Content = Faster Sales Cycles
• Buyers hate generic first calls.
• Instead, send a pre-recorded demo with timestamped highlights.
• Let buyers self-educate before the meeting, so calls focus on unique pain points.

4) Centralize Information in a Digital Sales Room like
• Sales decks get buried in email threads.
• A Digital Sales Room keeps all key content in one place
• Now your deal stays top-of-mind—even when you’re not in the room.

5) Multi-Thread by Personalizing Follow-Ups
• Champions struggle to sell internally. Make it easy for them.
• Instead of one generic follow-up email, send custom messages to each stakeholder.
• Give your champion everything they need to move the deal forward without needing another meeting.

The best sales teams aren’t forcing more meetings.
They’re embedding themselves in the buyer’s decision-making process—without being intrusive.

What is your opinion on the future of B2B buying?


--
️ 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗼𝘀𝘁 to help other Revenue Leaders.
 𝗦𝘂𝗯𝘀𝗰𝗿𝗶𝗯𝗲 to my Newsletter for Weekly Revenue Tips.

comments.commentText:

I think the major problem with all this is:
1. No proper training & enablement on how to engage with buyers in the first place
2. Most sellers still aren’t advisors, they are brought in to increase revenue but aren’t told that for that they need to find a way to help X amount of buyers per month
3. Just waiting for buyers to make up their mind in time is a dangerous game, no? I’m all for buyer-centric journeys and this definitely works for the big name that Personio has become…

BUT

If you wouldn’t have done those cold calls, emails, linkedin messages in the beginning I’m sure this wouldn’t have gone so fast.

It’s an allbound story and you preferably want to be everyone so your buyers can indeed:
1. See your stuff on the channel they are available most
2. Reply on their time when the timing is right
3. Be nurtured and advised, whether that’s through content or a call

For one of our customers we converted 500K ARR via email last year. Yes, they have inbound, yes they have content, but the effect of cold email?
Last minute getting a seat at the table of a vendor selection & winning a deal in 2 days time.
Buyers now expect flexibility and self-service. Meeting them where they are on their time makes sales more natural and effective.

postsData.content:
resilience+Rise Podcast: A conversation with Kal Dosanjh: Part 1

From the Streets to Solutions:’s Mission to Empower Youth

A single encounter with a 15-year-old struggling with addiction led to a powerful realization—these kids aren’t just statistics; they are products of their environment, in need of support and guidance.

This week on the Resilience+Rise podcast, we sit down with Kal Dosanjh, a veteran police officer with 25 years of service, including 8 years patrolling Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside. His journey from witnessing the harsh realities of street life to creating impactful solutions is one you won’t want to miss.

Kal's story isn't just about law enforcement; it's about understanding the root causes of crime and creating real, lasting change.

Kal shares his experiences in one of North America's most challenging environments, describing the complex socio-economic factors that contribute to the open-air drug market and the cycle of violence. He talks about the "perfect storm" of social housing, mental health challenges, and organized crime that plagues the Downtown Eastside. But more importantly, he shares the pivotal moment that shifted his focus from reactive policing to proactive community building.

This realization led Kal to found the KidsPlay Foundation, a registered charity dedicated to providing youth with positive alternatives. He explains the six streams of KidsPlay's work – education, sports, mentorship, environment, clinical counseling, and community patrol – and shares inspiring stories of kids whose lives have been transformed. From educational field trips to sports programs and mentorship opportunities, KidsPlay offers a lifeline to vulnerable youth, helping them develop valuable skills and make positive choices. Kal's powerful "mahout" metaphor perfectly illustrates the importance of instilling positive values early in life.

Join me, Thomas Scaria, ultra-marathoner and resilience coach, as I talk with Kal about his incredible journey, the challenges facing inner-city youth, and the transformative power of hope and opportunity. This is a conversation that will leave you inspired and motivated to make a difference.

Tune in to the Resilience+Rise podcast now! (Full Podcast & connection in the comments)
